newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-APEC energy meeting to eye private sector.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-APEC energy meeting to eye private sector.

text.p: The role of private investment in the expanding energy industries of Asia will be a key topic among the business and government representatives from 18 countries gathering in Sydney next week to attend the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) energy ministers meeting.

A high level of private sector participation in the meeting and related functions under the umbrella of "APEC Energy Week" reflects concerns over ways of financing new power projects to meet forecast increases in energy demand in Asia, industry officials said on Friday.
Energy ministers also will consider endorsing 14 non-binding principles agreed to in 1994 to stimulate regional initiatves to reform industry policies.
The principles broadly cover a range of issues, including the opening of energy markets, removal of subsidies, environmental costs and cross-member cooperation to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
APEC estimates its member economies consume about half the world's energy and that demand will expand in line with forecast economic growth of 3.3 percent a year to 2010 in the region.

APEC expects energy consumption among its members to grow by around 2.2 percent a year to 2010, compared with only 1.0 percent a year for the area represented under the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD).
Against this backdrop, APEC members must struggle with the reality that as a whole they are net importers of energy, countered only partially by coal exports.

"The challenge for sustained growth in the Asian Pacific region over the next decade is an adequate supply of energy, particularly electricity," Australiam Resources and Energy Minister Warwick Parer said in a statement.
A separate forum headed by Parer will next week propose a programme to reduce risks among private industry in participating in power infrastructure projects in the region.
The growth in demand for newly-industrialising APEC economies is higher at over four percent a year, APEC said.

Ministers and representatives from the United States, Mexico, Thailand and China plan to address regional electricty market reforms, focusing on deregualtion issues, privatisation and project financing options.
Australian Prime Minister John Howard is scheduled to deliver a keynote address to the conference on August 28.

APEC groups Australia, Brunei, Canada, Chile, China, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, the Philippines, Singapore, Chinese Taipei, Thailand, and the United States.
